image.altText: Dams containing small amounts of water can be seen in drought-affected farming area located west of Melbourne,

props.synopsis: The Bureau of Meteorology formally declares an El Niño weather event, months after the World Meteorological Organization announced the same. Follow live.

title.children: Bureau of Meteorology formally declares El Niño weather event as hot and dry conditions sweep south-east Australia

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Southern Oscillation Index or the "90-day average" was the criteria the Bureau were waiting on. They now say they've met three of their four criteria. "It ticked over last week for the first time," Dr Karl Braganza says. "It has been bumping around so we were waiting another week to see that it had settled into that pattern. "This week we have confirmed that." But the trade winds haven't reversed as they have previously, only "weakened".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What criteria were we waiting for?

children.content: The
Southern Oscillation Index
or the "90-day average" was the criteria the Bureau were waiting on.
They now say they've met three of their four criteria.
"It ticked over last week for the first time," Dr Karl Braganza says.
"It has been bumping around so we were waiting another week to see that it had settled into that pattern.
"This week we have confirmed that."
But the trade winds haven't reversed as they have previously, only "weakened".

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Dr Karl Braganza says we're likely in for a hot summer, and the Bureau will be "closely monitoring" how dry things get — in case fire risks rise.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: El Niño expected to last until the end of summer

children.content: Dr Karl Braganza says we're likely in for a hot summer, and the Bureau will be "closely monitoring" how dry things get — in case fire risks rise.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Bureau's Dr Karl Braganza says: "When these things occur together, it tends to increase the rainfall deficiencies in the south-east of the continent over spring." He says there is an elevated risk of fire danger and extreme heat, but we haven't seen extended drought in the lead up to these conditions.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The BOM says we're also in a positive Indian Ocean Dipole

props.alt: A man speaking in front of BOM poster

children.content: (ABC News)
The Bureau's Dr Karl Braganza says:
"When these things occur together, it tends to increase the rainfall deficiencies in the south-east of the continent over spring."
He says there is an elevated risk of fire danger and extreme heat, but we haven't seen extended drought in the lead up to these conditions.

image.altText: two men talking to the media, one is wearing glasses

props.synopsis: In Labor's first NSW budget in more than a decade, Treasurer Daniel Mookhey increases a tax on big multinationals to fund a promised $3.6 billion in pay rises for public sector workers. Follow live.

title.children: NSW Labor hands down first budget in a decade, spruiks 'new age' of public investment

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Cost of living has been at the forefront of everyone's mind in recent months, including the treasurer's. There are some measures included in the budget, such as changes to rebates and allowances for families and seniors. Paige has found some sweet treats in this budget: -	From July 1, 2024 the family energy rebate will increase to $250, the seniors energy rebate will rise to $250 and the low-income household rebate will go up to $350 -	To honour their election promise, the government will introduce a $60 weekly toll cap from January 1, 2024 -	A new means-tested $50 active and creative kids combined voucher issued twice per year will roll out from February next year. It will help kids participate in sports and creative programs. -	There will be free general admission to the Australian Museum and Museums of History. This will cost the government $28.3 million over four years. -	Eligible seniors, pensions and veterans will receive discounted or concessional National Park passes -	Paid ticketing for foreshore viewing spots at the Sydney New Year's Eve fireworks will end which means everyone can attend for free. This will cost the government around $3 million each year. -	Frea parking at all rural and regional public hospitals began from August 1. This costs the government $19 million over four years.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What can you expect to help ease cost of living pressures

children.content: Cost of living has been at the forefront of everyone's mind in recent months, including the treasurer's.
There are some measures included in the budget, such as changes to rebates and allowances for families and seniors.
Paige has found some sweet treats in this budget:
-	From July 1, 2024 the family energy rebate will increase to $250, the seniors energy rebate will rise to $250 and the low-income household rebate will go up to $350
-	To honour their election promise, the government will introduce a $60 weekly toll cap from January 1, 2024
-	A new means-tested $50 active and creative kids combined voucher issued twice per year will roll out from February next year. It will help kids participate in sports and creative programs.
-	There will be free general admission to the Australian Museum and Museums of History. This will cost the government $28.3 million over four years.
-	Eligible seniors, pensions and veterans will receive discounted or concessional National Park passes
-	Paid ticketing for foreshore viewing spots at the Sydney New Year's Eve fireworks will end which means everyone can attend for free. This will cost the government around $3 million each year.
-	Frea parking at all rural and regional public hospitals began from August 1. This costs the government $19 million over four years.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The treasurer's speech in the Lower House of parliament has begun. Daniel Mookhey said this budget aimed to end "the era of privatisation". Sarah Gerathy reports: He's actually from the Upper House — which is unusual for a Treasurer, but the budget speech is always delivered to the Lower House. The last time a treasurer was an Upper House member was in 2010. "This Labor budget signals the beginning of a new age of public investment that benefits the many, bringing and an end to the era of privatisation that handed profits to the few," Mr Mookhey said. "This Labor budget delivers the people of New South Wales the fresh start they voted for, busting the wages cap, beginning toll reform, backing first home buyers, building new and better public schools and hospitals."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Daniel Mookhey is speaking now, spruiks 'new age' of public investment

children.content: The treasurer's speech in the Lower House of parliament has begun.
Daniel Mookhey said this budget aimed to end "the era of privatisation".
Sarah Gerathy
reports:
He's actually from the Upper House — which is unusual for a Treasurer, but the budget speech is always delivered to the Lower House.
The last time a treasurer was an Upper House member was in 2010.
"This Labor budget signals the beginning of a new age of public investment that benefits the many, bringing and an end to the era of privatisation that handed profits to the few," Mr Mookhey said.

"This Labor budget delivers the people of New South Wales the fresh start they voted for, busting the wages cap, beginning toll reform, backing first home buyers, building new and better public schools and hospitals."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Among the big items are billions set aside for health facilities, schools and Sydney's new metro train lines. There is also $300 million for housing, including plans for more than 1,400 affordable dwellings by the financial year 2039-40. Another $5 million has been allocated toward a 12-month consultation process for a "pathway to Treaty" with First Nations peoples. More from Isobel: This budget focuses spending on schools, hospitals and public sector wages — almost all of which had already been announced before today's budget. It includes: •	$13.8 billion into health facilities, including new money for Fairfield Hospital Redevelopment and $400 million for the new Rouse Hill Hospital, on top of $300 million committed by the previous Coalition government. •	$9.8 billion for schools and educational facilities •	$72.3 billion into transport projects, including the Sydney Metro West and the Sydney Metro — Western Sydney Airport connection •	$3.2 billion for disaster relief and recovery programs •	$2.2 billion for a Housing and Infrastructure Plan A previously announced review into the viability and cost of the Sydney Metro is due to be given to government by the end of the year, the budget documents said. As part of the Housing and Infrastructure Plan, there is $300 million for publicly owned company Landcom housing to deliver "an additional 1,409 affordable homes and 3,288 market homes to 2039-40." The budget papers show in addition to another affordable housing program, the state will build about 9,300 new social, affordable and private homes in the next 16 years. But Mr Mookhey expected 3000 of those to be built by the end of the decade. Mr Mookhey blamed the previous government for contributing to the housing crisis. "If we had built more homes in the last decade we would have more homes in this decade," he said. Some smaller expenses are also notable. There is $5 million towards a 12-month consultation towards a "pathway to Treaty" with First Nations Australians.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What are the big ticket expenses?

children.content: Among the big items are billions set aside for health facilities, schools and Sydney's new metro train lines.
There is also $300 million for housing, including plans for more than 1,400 affordable dwellings by the financial year 2039-40.
Another $5 million has been allocated toward a 12-month consultation process for a "pathway to Treaty" with First Nations peoples.
More from Isobel:
This budget focuses spending on schools, hospitals and public sector wages — almost all of which had already been announced before today's budget.
It includes:

•	$13.8 billion into health facilities, including new money for Fairfield Hospital Redevelopment and $400 million for the new Rouse Hill Hospital, on top of $300 million committed by the previous Coalition government.
•	$9.8 billion for schools and educational facilities
•	$72.3 billion into transport projects, including the Sydney Metro West and the Sydney Metro — Western Sydney Airport connection
•	$3.2 billion for disaster relief and recovery programs
•	$2.2 billion for a Housing and Infrastructure Plan
A previously announced review into the viability and cost of the Sydney Metro is due to be given to government by the end of the year, the budget documents said.
As part of the Housing and Infrastructure Plan, there is $300 million for publicly owned company Landcom housing to deliver "an additional 1,409 affordable homes and 3,288 market homes to 2039-40."
The budget papers show in addition to another affordable housing program, the state will build about 9,300 new social, affordable and private homes in the next 16 years.
But Mr Mookhey expected 3000 of those to be built by the end of the decade.
Mr Mookhey blamed the previous government for contributing to the housing crisis.
"If we had built more homes in the last decade we would have more homes in this decade," he said.
Some smaller expenses are also notable.
There is $5 million towards a 12-month consultation towards a "pathway to Treaty" with First Nations Australians.

image.altText: Kris holding medicine with a dog on an outdoor couch
